uOvySrSg.question: For a given configuration, the stall speed of an aeroplane will be highest when loaded

options.text: to the maximum allowable mass with the most forward CG.
to a low total mass with the most forward CG.
to a low total mass with the most aft CG.
to the maximum allowable mass with the most aft CG.

X3SXPEpO.question: The effect of operating an aeroplane with a CG too far forward is to experience:

options.text: inability or difficulty in flaring on touchdown, resulting in nose-wheel landing first.
lower stick forces per G loading.
lower stalling speed.
inability or difficulty in trimming when flaps are retracted.

JGUDlaiH.question: When considering the effects of increased mass on an aeroplane, which of the following is true?

options.text: Stalling speeds will be higher.
Gradient of climb for a given power setting will be higher.
Stalling speeds will be lower.
Flight endurance will be increased.

LGKLiNwO.question: What happens when the centre of gravity (CG) is moved in a forward direction?

options.text: A reduction in rate of climb capability.
A reduction in the specific fuel consumption.
A decrease in induced drag.
A increase in rate of climb capability.

xRyQV3SQ.question: What happens if the CG is aft of the rear limit?

options.text: Stability decreases.
Stability increases.
Control forces will increase.
Controllability decreases.

31jRhro4.question: What is the effect of a forward CG on the time to reach cruising altitude?

options.text: A forward CG decreases the maximum Rate of Climb and increases the time to reach cruising altitude.
The CG position has no impact on the Rate of Climb.
A forward CG allows the selection of a higher cruising altitude, therefore increases the time to reach cruising altitude.
A forward CG increases the maximum Rate of Climb and decreases the time to reach cruising altitude.

jzmEizMC.question: What is a possible consequence of loading an aircraft incorrectly so that the Centre of Gravity is positioned ahead of the forward limit?

options.text: There may be insufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level,
There may be insufficient forward pitch control available to keep the aircraft level.
There may be a tendency to over-pitch the aircraft during the flare just before landing.
The aircraft may become excessively manoeuvrable and beyond control.

VIJ5QtTi.question: What is a possible consequence of loading an aircraft incorrectly so that the Centre of Gravity is positioned ahead of the forward limit?

options.text: There may be insufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level.
There may be insufficient forward pitch control available to keep the aircraft level.
The aircraft may become excessively manoeuvrable and beyond control.
There may be a tendency to over-pitch the aircraft during the flare just before landing.

oySSD08G.question: What is a possible consequence of loading an aircraft incorrectly so that the Centre of Gravity is positioned ahead of the forward limit?

options.text: The aircraft becomes excessively stable and requires larger control inputs.
The aircraft may become excessively manoeuvrable and beyond control.
There may be insufficient forward pitch control available to keep the aircraft level.
There may be a tendency to over-pitch the aircraft during the flare just before landing.

K37qoY96.question: To assess aircraft performance, the pilot must...

options.text: know the planned take-off, en-route and landing mass, and any subsequent changes due to changes from the load and trim documentation.
only use the certified mass information from the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM).
assess the actual zero fuel mass from the load and trim documentation and make sure that it does not exceed the certified limit.
know the mass of the aircraft at the previous landing and add a proper increment of fuel to the actual mass to get the correct values of uplifted fuel.

oiVxfUif.question: If an aeroplane has a higher mass than anticipated, for a given airspeed, the angle of attack will:

options.text: be greater, drag will increase and endurance will decrease.
remain constant, drag will increase and endurance will increase.
be decreased, drag will decrease and endurance will increase.
remain constant, drag will decrease and endurance will decrease.

m1MzGlcP.question: In which of the following situations must a pilot calculate the take-off mass and the centre of gravity and check the values against the limits?

options.text: Always before each flight
Always after each flight.
As soon as the load is different to the load from the last flight.
In predetermined intervals.

cWnKRPcB.question: In which of the following situations must a pilot calculate the take-off mass and the centre of gravity and check the values against the limits?

options.text: Always before each flight.
As soon as the load is different to the load from the last flight.
In predetermined intervals.
Always after each flight.

eef49zei.question: The handling and performance problems encountered with a CG too far aft include:

options.text: degradation or loss of nose-wheel steering.
improvement in nose-wheel steering.
no likelihood of a nose-up overbalance (on a tricycle gear aircraft) on the ground resulting in tail damage.
higher stick forces per G loading with no risk of over-stressing the airframe in manoeuvers.

CerFsViM.question: What are the effects on stability and controllability of a CG behind the aft limit? Longitudinal stability...

options.text: is reduced and controllability is increased.
is increased and controllability is reduced.
and controllability are increased.
and controllability are reduced.

7FZqhUy6.question: Following the acceptance of the Load Sheet and the Operational Flight Plan, the Commander decides to refuel his/her aircraft with 1618 US gallons at a specific gravity of 0.8. The fuel mass loaded on board is...

options.text: 754 lb

UOGTcaT0.question: If the CG is forward of the maximum forward CG limit, and if you compensate it with nose up action, the...

options.text: drag increases.
stall speed decreases.
fuel consumption decreases.
maneuverability increases.

MyZiEWWb.question: What is possible consequences of loading an aircraft incorrectly so that CG is positioned behind the aft limit?

options.text: There may be insufficient forward pitch control available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.
The aircraft will be extremely stable.
There may be an inability to flare the aircraft on landing.
There may be insufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.

hXYr64yr.question: Which CG position is used when determining minimum control speeds in performance? A CG..

options.text: at the aft limit.
at the forward limit.
mid of the aft and forward limits.
at the average position.

UwlOCeSH.question: What are the effects of a CG in front of the forward limit? Range

options.text: and absolute ceiling decrease.
decreases and absolute ceiling increases.
increases and absolute ceiling decreases.
and absolute ceiling increase.

XJScShIM.question: Due to incorrect loading the centre of gravity (CG) of an airplane is located in front of the forward limit. What could be the consequence?

options.text: The available aft pitch control could be insufficient to keep the airplane in level flight.
The airplane is likely to over-pitch shortly before touchdown (during flare).
An extremely manoeuvrable airplane beyond control.
The available forward pitch control could be insufficient to keep the airplane in level flight.

aSg4MvAg.question: Comparing a forward CG position with an aft one, the forward CG position will cause a:

options.text: decrease in range.
tendency to yaw to the right on take-off.
decrease of the stalling speed.
decrease in the landing speed.

GlDEDb9h.question: When does the centre of gravity position and Take-off Mass have to be calculated and checked against the limits?

options.text: Before each flight.
If the load is different from the last flight.
After each flight.
In specified intervals.

3ASVIovW.question: If nose wheel moves aft during gear retraction, how will this movement affect the location of the centre of gravity (CG) on the aircraft?

options.text: It will cause the CG to move aft.
It will not affect the CG location.
It will cause the CG to move forward.
The CG location will change, but the direction cannot be told from the information given.

ZwqSXuam.question: If nose wheel moves aft during gear retraction, how will this movement affect the location of the centre of gravity (CG) on the aircraft?

options.text: It will cause the CG to move aft.
The CG location will change, but the direction in which it moves cannot be deduced from the information given.
It will cause the CG to move forward.
It will not affect the CG location.

nVSJ2Syg.question: If nose wheel moves aft during gear retraction, how will this movement affect the location of the centre of gravity (cg) on the aircraft?

options.text: It will cause the cg to move aft.
The cg location will change, but the direction cannot be told the information given.
It will not affect the cg location.
It will cause the cg to move forward.

AitGqJvy.question: What are the effects of a CG forward of the forward limit?

options.text: Range, endurance and absolute ceiling will decrease
Endurance, range increase and absolute ceiling will decrease
Endurance, range decrease and absolute ceiling will increase
Endurance, range and absolute ceiling will increase

Q0bt6oFq.question: If the centre of gravity is on the aft limit in level and forward flight, the..

options.text: range is increased.
fuel consumption is increased.
range is not affected.
control forces are decreased.

LidbitrZ.question: What is the importance of accurately knowing the aircraft mass during flight? Accurate masses..

options.text: allow selection of the real, optimum cruising flight level.
allow airlines to better compute navigation and route charges.
are unimportant since all performance decisions are based on expected masses on the operational flight plan.
are only required for take-off and landing, to comply with loadsheet requirements.
simplified, scaled-down value of a moment.
fuel-loading index used in fuel density calculations.
wing-loading index used in ground handling.
floor-loading index to simplify aircraft loading.

afFk1YOF.question: What effect does the CG on the aft limit have on the fuel flow of an aeroplane?

options.text: Decreases
Increases
No effect
Marginal increase

bvIQMmCu.question: If other factors are unchanged, the fuel mileage (nautical miles per kg) is:

options.text: lower with a forward centre of gravity position.
independent from the centre of gravity position.
lower with an aft centre of gravity position.
higher with a forward centre of gravity position.

nFCxJtwf.question: What is the effect of having the CG forward of the forward limit?

options.text: Increase in drag.
Increased manoeuvrability.
Decrease in stall speed.
Decreased landing distance required.

8pWQJO7H.question:
What effect does a CG outside the aft limit have on aircraft longitudinal 

stability and controllability?

options.text: Decreases stability and increases controllability
NO change
Increases Both
Decreases Both

BcV2HDIG.question: What effect does a CG outside the aft limit have on aircraft longitudinal stability and controllability?

options.text: Decreases stability and increases controllability.
Increases stability and decreases controllability.
Increases both.
Decreases both.

rZU5fNGL.question: An aeroplane is said to be neutrally stable. This is likely to:

options.text: be caused by a centre of gravity, which is towards the rearward limit.
be caused by a centre of gravity, which is towards the forward limit.
be totally unrelated to the position of the centre of gravity.
cause the centre of gravity to move forwards.

008sxxOP.question: If during flight a considerable amount of fuel was transferred from a fuel tank located in the forward fuselage section to a fuel tank located at the rear section of the fuselage, what effect would this have on the aircraft?

options.text: Increase in range and decrease in stall speed.
Increase in range and stall speed.
Increase in stability and decrease in trim drag.
Increase in stability and trim drag.

ya3oV7wy.question: What will be the effect on the longitudinal static stability, if the Centre of Gravity (CG) is located behind the aft CG limit?

options.text: Stability decreases beyond acceptable limits.
Longitudinal stability is NOT related to the position of the CG.
There is a significant increase in stability.
The flight control forces increase.

dlEoG27u.question: Assuming gross mass, altitude and airspeed remain unchanged, movement of the centre of gravity from the forward to the aft limit will cause:

options.text: increased cruise range.
higher stall speed.
lower optimum cruising speed.
reduced maximum cruise range.

PEooJVd6.question: If the CG is further forwards than the forward limit, the aircraft's horizontal surfaces have a...

options.text: Longer than usual moment arm and the fuel consumption is increased.
Longer than usual moment arm and the fuel consumption is decreased.
Shorter than usual moment arm and the drag is decreased.
Shorter than usual moment arm and the range is increased.

xlALd2Ku.question: When determining the minimum control speeds for an aeroplane, which of the following CG positions is used?

options.text: The aft CG limit.
An average CG position.
A CG location mid of the aft and forward limits.
The forward CG limit.

xaiEDxpq.question:
Which statement is correct?

I. Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the forward limit. 
 II. Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.

options.text: I is correct, II is correct.
I is correct, II is incorrect.
I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

vQrZuieV.question: Which of the following has to be expected with a CG in front of the forward limit?

options.text: An increase in aircraft drag.
A greater maximum endurance and range.
An increase in take-off distance and a reduction in landing distance.
Excessive longitudinal instability.

mvjoUArM.question: Which of the following has to be expected with a CG in front of the forward limit?

options.text: A reduction in aircraft ceiling.
A reduction of maximum range, but constant maximum endurance.
Static instability and increased maneuverability.
A reduction in total drag.

C3tQVW9I.question: Which one of the following describes a possible handling and performance problem encountered with a CG too far aft?

options.text: Degradation or loss of nose-wheel steering.
Improvement in nose-wheel steering.
No likelihood of a nose-up overbalance (on a tricycle gear aircraft) on the ground resulting in tail damage.
Decreased tendency to skid.

uIVXUqAl.question: The Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is a structural limiting mass. It is made up of the aeroplane Dry Operating Mass (DOM) plus:

options.text: Traffic Load.
Traffic Load, unusable fuel and crew standard mass.
unusable fuel and crew standard mass.
Traffic Load and crew standard mass.

9gAnNDB2.question: What determines the longitudinal stability of an aeroplane ?

options.text: The location of the centre of gravity with respect to the neutral point.
The dihedral, angle of sweepback and the keel effect.
The relationship of thrust and lift to weight and drag.
The effectiveness of the horizontal stabilizer, rudder and rudder trim tab.

E8FTltTs.question: What determines the longitudinal stability of an aeroplane?

options.text: The location of the centre of gravity with respect to the neutral point.
The dihedral, angle of sweepback and the keel effect.
The effectiveness of the horizontal stabilizer, rudder and rudder trim tab.
The relationship of thrust and lift to weight and drag.

YSC0Mygo.question: With the centre of gravity (CG) on the forward limit which of the following is to be expected?

options.text: A decrease in range.
A decrease of the stalling speed.
A decrease in the landing speed.
A tendency to yaw to the right on take-off.

N4fg6M1Q.question: For the following see-saw to be in balance

options.text: Fc = Fa  3
Fc = 3  Fa
Fc = 3  Fa
Fc = Fa  3A

hiQO2x0i.question: For the following see-saw to be in balance

options.text: Fb = A  Fa  B
Fb = A + Fa  B
Fb = B  Fa  A
Fb = A  B  Fa

QjwkV1j6.question: Which of the following is most likely to affect the range of centre of gravity positions on an aeroplane?

options.text: Elevator and tailplane (horizontal stabilizer) effectiveness in all flight conditions.
The need to maintain a low value of stalling speed.
The need to minimize drag forces and so improve efficiency.
Location of the undercarriage.

BOP94oyW.question: Which of the following is most likely to affect the range of centre of gravity positions on an aeroplane?

options.text: The effectiveness of elevator and tailplane (horizontal stabilizer) in all flight conditions.
The need to maintain low stalling speed.
The location of the undercarriage.
The need to minimize drag forces and improve efficiency.

5TFwbYW7.question: For a given aeroplane mass, a more aft CG position will..

options.text: decrease the take-off distance and improve the take-off climb performance.
increase the take-off distance and reduce the take-off climb performance.
decrease the take-off distance and reduce the take-off climb performance.
increase the take-off distance and improve the take-off climb performance.

phKX3apx.question: What is the effect if the centre of gravity is behind the aft limit in level and forward flight?

options.text: The stability is decreased.
The control forces are decreased.
The controllability is increased.
The stability is increased.

zJUQ3vKO.question: What is the effect if the centre of gravity is behind the aft limit in level and forward flight?

options.text: The stability is decreased.
The control forces are increased.
The controllability is decreased.
The stability is increased.

GXD1Yo7o.question: The stalling speed of an aeroplane will be highest when it is loaded with a

options.text: high gross mass and forward centre of gravity.
low gross mass and forward centre of gravity.
high gross mass and aft centre of gravity.
low gross mass and aft centre of gravity.

aga4cqcJ.question: Choose the correct statement as related to infants travel in aircraft:

options.text: an infant is a person between the ages of 0 years to 2 years.
an infant seated on an adult's lap increases the passenger's mass by 35 kg.
an infant is a person between the ages of 0 years to 3 years.
an infant must always be seated in its own seat and accounted for as 35 kg.

BtMB2imM.question: The C.G. limits are from 5 inches forward to 7 inches aft of the datum. If the MAC is 41 inches and its leading edge is 15 inches forward of the datum, what are the C.G. limits as % MAC

options.text: Fwd limit 24.3%, Aft limit 53.6%
Fwd limit 36.6%, Aft limit 53.6%
Fwd limit 12.2%, Aft limit 29.3%
Fwd limit 29.3%, Aft limit 36.6%

pdpE7Ey9.question: The operating mass of an aeroplane is:

options.text: Dry operating mass plus the take-off fuel mass
Empty mass plus the trip fuel mass
The empty mass plus crew, crew baggage and catering
Empty mass plus the take-off fuel mass

7714ggIU.question: An operator has 19 aircraft of the same type and wants to use fleet mass values. Select the number of aircraft that will have to be weighted on the initial weighing and the subsequent weighings:

options.text: initially 19 thereafter 7
initially 10 thereafter 14
initially 10 thereafter 7
initially 19 thereafter 14

PIVD24nB.question: The weight of an aircraft, which is in level non accelerated flight, is said to act:

options.text: vertically through the centre of gravity.
always along the vertical axis of the aeroplane.
vertically through the centre of pressure.
vertically through the datum point.

options.text: Forward limit 90.6", aft limit 94.6"

QEZ2n5Yi.question: For a take-off in a large aeroplane, what is the relationship between the CG and the stabiliser trim setting?

options.text: With a more aft CG, a lower nose-up stabiliser trim setting is required.
The location of the CG does NOT affect the stabiliser trim setting for take-off.
With a more forward CG, a more nose-down stabiliser trim setting is required.
With a more aft CG, the greater nose-up stabiliser trim setting is required.

tJ6ipP8c.question: If both the nose and the main landing gears of a large transport aircraft retract forward, what would be the effect on the CG when lowering the gear?

options.text: CG will move aft.
CG will move forward.
CG will initially move forward then aft.
CG will remain static.

kSY6CeC8.question: During take-off, the load is suddenly sliding and moving backwards. What happens to the aircraft's CG and stability?

options.text: CG moves aft and stability decreases.
CG moves forward and stability increases.
CG moves aft and stability increases.
CG moves forward and stability decreases.
